Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2008 05:04PM swimangel72 wrote: Hi Bernice - I'm so sorry to hear your news - but I hope I can reassure you that Navelbine isn't all that difficult to tolerate. I'm a weird case - my onc put me on Navelbine even though my tumor was Stage 1 Grade 1 - because I'm Her2+, he wanted me on Herceptin, but Herceptin works better in combination with other chemo drugs. He chose Navelbine for me because of its light side-effects - it won't cause any heart problems (Herceptin will) and it won't cause total hair loss (although my hair has gotten thinner.) I get my infusions every two weeks. The main side effects I've experienced with Navelbine are as follows:  burning and heavy feeling in my arm (they tried a medi-port for me, but after it got infected, they're using my veins.) The solution to the burning feeling was for the nurse to run the Navelbine at the SAME time as a bag of saline - the arm pain (which had lasted a week) was totally gone! The other side effect I experience is painless diarhhea - it hits me about 2 hours after my infusion and lasts for about 4 hours. Then it's totally gone. When I switched oncs, the new nurses gave me (as they routinely do) premeds: Decadron (a steroid) and Zofran (anti-nausea meds). This was unnecessary for me since I never got nauseous on the Navelbine and Herceptin. The premeds were AWFUL - the Decadron kept me up all night for two nights in a row - and the Zofran gave me painful constipation for 3 days - my belly swelled up and the cramping was so bad I felt like I was giving birth! So I told them to forget the pre-meds - they cause more problems than they cured. So I'm back now to just Navelbine (with saline) and Herceptin. The only other side effect I noticed is a bit of tiredness - but that could be from the Herceptin - or from anxiety. Otherwise I've been perfectly fine - and once they removed the infected port, I was able to return to swimming and my energy level has been getting better every week. The onc does check my counts every week - but so far they haven't dropped low enough for any concern. I hope my story gives you confidence Bernice that Navelbine will be much easier to tolerate than your prior chemo experiences. Hang in there - and be sure to tell the nurses any side effects you experience.

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2011 06:22PM - edited Jan 22, 2011 06:25PM by swimangel72 Barry - has your tumor been tested to see if it's Her2+? That made all the difference in my treatment - even though my tumor was only a Stage 1, Grade 1, ER+ and PR+ - even with an Oncotype DX score of 22 (which is low-intermediate) I had a uni-lateral mx with immediate reconstruction (and a lot of infections afterwards). I should have just waited to make this decision after getting the breast MRI (which showed no other abnormalities). A lumpectomy with rads has the same survival rates as a mastectomy...........however..........the more important decision you'll have to make will be concerning chemo treatment - do you need it or not? Did you get an Oncotype DX test done? Was your tumor Her2- or equivacal? If equivacal, you need to get the FISh test done - if the tumor is Her2+, you'll need Herceptin with chemo for a year. I understand how difficult all these decisions are............good luck and may God's angels watch over you! P.S. Edited to add - after my breast cancer dx 3 years ago, my thyroid was tested and showed to be hypothyroid and was immediately put on a low dose of Synthroid every day. It never interfered with any of my chemo/Herceptin/Arimidex treatments.

Posts.Content: Jun 11, 2010 08:34PM swimangel72 wrote: Navygirl - my PS promised me a Diep - yet he took a "small cuff of muscle" when he dissected the perforators, which means I really had a "muscle-sparing free tram".........so you are right not to trust your PS. Mollydog - I discovered the truth about my surgery by obtaining the operative reports from the hospital - anyone can request their reports, they belong to you. I ended up asking for the reports after being encouraged to do so by my insurance company follow-up nurse (who was the best support person I had during my long ordeal). She would call me every two weeks and gave me fantastic advice. I started doubting that I received a true Diep when I saw a bulge just above my abdominal incision - my PS was so dishonest - he kept suggesting that I gained weight (I lost weight) or that it was "post-surgical swelling". After I saw my operative reports, I went to my PCP and he ordered a Cat scan. Even then, the radiologist did not see a hernia - but he did report on a defective abdominal muscle. Thanks to BethNYC here at bc.org, I went to a hernia specialist with my CD - he took one look at it, then showed me the scan on his laptop and said that it WAS a hernia - but a radiologist wouldn't notice it because the scan was taken while I was laying down. This surgeon had me stand up and cough while he placed his hands on the bulge - this was proof that I had a hernia - the cat scan showed that I had no muscle remaining on the right side where the PS took the perforators. I needed open abdominal surgery (which took place a year after my so-called "diep") and the hernia surgeon worked with a plastic surgeon to place a biologic mesh material - they also tightened up my muscles and supported the mesh so I should never experience another hernia again. Repeat hernias are common after hernia repairs, especially with mesh that isn't biologic. The mesh they used on me was called Strattice - made by the same company that makes Alloderm. This summer will be my first summer without surgery in two years - and I'm so grateful for BC.ORG and the wonderful people here who have helped me.   I hope my info has helped you - there's a lot of info here at bc.org about hernias - just do a Search - there's an article buried here somewhere where it states that women who have had prior abdominal surgery run a 25% increase risk of hernia after a Diep.......the risk for hernia after a muscle-sparing free tram is even higher. Good luck and I hope anyone who experiences a hernia after breast reconstruction surgery can find an experienced hernia surgery as wonderful as mine (Dr. George DeNoto - North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset NY on Long Island - he works with Dr. Ron Israeli a wonderful plastic surgeon who's practice is devoted to breast reconstruction. You can see his web site at www.breastreconstruction.org

Posts.Content: Oct 3, 2008 08:59PM - edited Oct 3, 2008 09:07PM by swimangel72 Renee - what is your complete pathology? Are you Her2+ or BRCA positive?  There are so many new treatments today for women with bc - my own attitude about mastectomy was totally influenced by women my mother's age.......times have REALLY changed a lot since then. I hope you'll slow down a bit and think this through very carefully. Have you spoken to an oncologist yet? You sound a lot like I was back in February when I was first dx'd............I had barely a month between my dx and my surgery. I let fear totally overcome my mind - and stubborn stoicism determine my decision. I really would have been fine with a lumpectomy and radiation - but was very fearful of radiation and so chose a unilateral skin-sparing masectomy followed by an immediate Diep. Well things don't always work out for the best.  I didn't get a Diep, I got a "muscle-sparing free tram" - and I got something I never anticipated - a MRSA staph infection in my abdomen, which caused about 8 inches of my incision to reopen. It needed packing 2 times a day for over 3 months. Now I have a very large abdominal bulge which is really a hernia (the staph ate away most of the muscle on my right side) I need more abdominal surgery to repair this with a mesh. And the new "foob" isn't great to look at - it'll be OK after Stage 2 and possibly Stage 3 surgery, but it feels heavy and fake - has no sensation at all. Also my belly-button is weird and I have no feeling in my skin around that area either. Of course you may end up with a totally successful surgery without all these problems - many women do - but you'll have to do a lot of research to get a very experienced plastic surgeon. I THOUGHT I had a very experienced Diep plastic surgeon -but even so I ended up with big problems. I also ended up with stage 1 lymphedema in my right arm...........fortunately I only had one breast removed, so my left arm is still useable for blood draws and my Herceptin tx. Having both breasts removed does increase your risk for lyphedema in both arms AND in your trunk.  So why put yourself through all this if a lumpectomy and rads have the same recurrence rates as mastectomy? Back when I made my decision - I didn't know that fact - I thought mastectomy had much lower recurrence rates - but newer studies show that's not true. At least give yourself a chance to see if a lumpectomy and rads will work for you. You can always get a mastectomy later on. I wanted to do something to "put cancer behind me" - and instead, my huge scars are a constant reminder of what fear can do to a person, more damage than my .9 cm stage 1 tumor should have done.

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2009 03:07PM swimangel72 wrote: I trust word-of-mouth referrals the most, but always have my brother-in-law (a cardiologist) check out my doctors credentials. Still I've stumbled across several doctors that were just "not that into me". No matter how good their credentials or reputations, some doctors are still losers - here's a checklist of how to spot a BAD doctor (wish I knew this last year!): http://nosurrenderbreastcancerhelp.org/page16/page14/page14.html WARNING SIGNS OF A BAD DOCTOR: Talks to you only in the exam room while you are undressed 2. Never looks at you when you are speaking, but rather, writes furiously in your chart not listening to a word you say 3. Has not reviewed your case at all prior to your visit. You know this because while you are perched on the iron table in your paper dress waiting for him, you hear him leave the exam room of another patient, then he is standing outside your door and you hear him remove your chart from the little cubby on the front of your door, flip through a few pages for 30 seconds and then he comes in. THAT is not PREP. Either come in and open the chart and talk or review it before hand at your desk in a proper way. 4. He doesn't wash his hands upon entering. He just left another exam room- do you really want him touching you? 5. He makes no eye contact, isn't quite sure of your name and simply goes through the motions of an exam. Or worse, never touches you. Never lays hands on you but writes up five prescriptions anyway. 6. He acts as if we are all the same person- more like cars in a body shop than human. Once he opens the hood of a Chevy it is the same as a Ford. 7. He doesn't let you speak, ask questions, or express your fears 8. He doesn't seem to care that you have cancer. There is no empathy. He either tells you he can "cure you" or he says off hand "we'll see if this works" 9. When you question him about wanting a test or a certain chemo he makes a face because you "read it on the internet". He then proceeds to inform you that anything you read is wrong and he is the only one who is right. 10. He has the same routine with everyone, never thinks of you as an individual. You can tell from the way he is talking it is a rote speech he has delivered thousands of times. But he never puts YOU into the speech. You can tell your particular case is of no interest to him-he has done this thousands of times, he would like you to just be quiet and listen to what he has to say. 11. You express a fear about your hair falling out and he makes a joke and tells you to stop being vain. 12. He doesn't take into account the quality of your life when he is lining up one harsh treatment after another. 13. If you ask him about a side effect he says it "goes with the territory" 14. He makes you wait-not just in the waiting room but even in the exam room where you are left there waiting and waiting. At least in the waiting room there were magazines to read! Once in a while, and if an apology is given then it is fine, but every time with no apology is unacceptable 15. He is unavailable for after hours emergencies. OR if you finally do get through to him, he insinuates that you "bothered" him for nothing 16. He won't share your case and what he feels needs to be done with your other doctors. 17. He never calls you with test results. 18. He thinks you are overreacting and might need some kind of counseling, anti-depressant, tranquilizer, etc. or you have fibromyalgia-when if he took five minutes to put your mind at east you wouldn't need anything. 19. He won't let you bring your husband, brother, sister, or best friend in with you to discuss your case- all you are doing is taking up too much of his time. 20. He doesn't remember you. After six months of chemo he still has no clue who you are.... Don't wait six months to discover this. Six minutes will tell you a lot about your doctor!

Posts.Content: May 18, 2009 03:26PM swimangel72 wrote: MED - I responded to your other thread where you stated that your tumor was Her2 equivacol. It's extremely important to find out your Her2 status - your tumor sample should have immediately been sent out to a lab for a FISH test. Here's a link explaining about the FISH test: http://www.breastcancer.org/symptoms/testing/types/fish.jsp If your tumor turns out to be Her2+++ your onc should recommend chemo with Herceptin. Her2+ cancers are very aggressive no matter how small. If your onc isn't pursuing the FISH test you really need a second opinion. Good luck!

Posts.Content: Jul 5, 2008 10:03AM swimangel72 wrote: I get the early-morning tears, always when I get ready for a shower. This is when I look at myself completely in the mirror and feel down - I didn't lose my hair, but it is thinner. My abdominal scar has finally healed, but it remains a bright angry red, and feels like a tight band across my belly. My new "foob" is still too big and too flat - and my PS won't do Stage 2 until I finish my Herceptin next April. And my port scar is an ugly two inch scar - with an added "dimple" scar high in my neck. However - my sense of identity is tied to other people's view of me, rather than my own view of myself in a mirror. Thus I do much better when I'm engaging in conversation with people, or get busy helping people. Part of my problem is I'm just not involved enough with people outside my family - so the walls seems to close in and I get a lost feeling. Thus, I hope my feeling of "self" will return when I return to work in September. Still, I have lost a lot of my old zest, though I understand that this too is a process. Perhaps it has allowed me more quiet time to rethink my priorities. I haven't returned to work since my surgery back on March 3rd - and now the school is closed for summer. I stayed involved with everyone through emails, but so much time has passed, I feel disconnected from my old co-workers and my old job. I'll be returning to work in September - but it seems unreal, like it won't be the same. I'm nervous about returning and having everyone look me up-and-down and asking me a million questions. Part of me wants to quit my job and start something new - the other part is grateful that my job is waiting for me. The bottom line is - I am a changed person. For better or worse - there's no going back. But I need to stay mindful that all change is difficult. Life is nothing but change. So often I feel like a lump of rock........and the good and bad events in my life are like a river pouring over me, day after day, smoothing out my rough spots, making me harder, shinier, more resilient.......hopefully turning my rock-hard soul into a jewel that, at the end of my journey, would be bright enough to be picked up by God.

Posts.Content: May 11, 2009 09:44AM swimangel72 wrote: Great thread - thanks for starting it! My four months of chemo went very well but I was on a "light" chemo of Navelbine and Herceptin every two weeks. I wish I knew that a chemo port was unnecessary ............that with the right infusion nurse, who used saline along with the Navelbine, my veins worked just fine. I ended up with a port, but it never healed and after only a month it needed to be removed - so now I have an ugly scar which was totally useless. Also - thanks to these boards, I read that not everyone needs pre-meds. When I switched oncologists after a month, my new oncologist gave me steroids and an anti-nausea medication before my chemo. It caused the most awful constipation and tummy pain! Next time I told them forget the pre-meds - I was fine with just the Navelbine and Herceptin - I'd rather deal with the diarrhea all that night than suffer for three days with constipation! I was lucky my infusion nurse was an angel and a good communicator...........we never had any problems after that. So my #1 advice to everyone is - communicate with your nurse - learn to understand your own body's reaction to drugs. Research everything you can beforehand..........and be prepared for the unknown for our bodies are unique and special!

Posts.Content: May 18, 2009 03:19PM swimangel72 wrote: MED - your diagnosis is similar to mine - my tumor was also Her2 equivacol  but I had no positive nodes. My Oncotype score was 22 - and at first my onc said I wouldn't need chemo. Ten minutes later, he finally received my FISH report - and immediately changed his mind - because the report showed the tumor was Her2+++.  I had to go on a "light" chemo regime of Navelbine for 4 months with Herceptin continuing for a year. I didn't lose any hair or experience any heart problems. My onc told me that Herceptin could not be given alone but it worked well with Navelbine. Has your tumor sample been sent out for a FISH test? Most Her2 equivacal tumors must undergo the FISH test to get a definite answer. This will finalize the decision for you - if your tumor IS Her2+ then I'd be very very surprised if your onc still tells you no chemo - and I'd immediately seek out another opinion. Good luck with your difficult decision!

My abdominal muscles were desetroyed by the MRSA...........which necessitated opened abdominal surgery a year later to insert a mrsa-resistant mesh. I am only now getting my strength back. So - as you can imagine - my advice to you is fight your bronchitis now and do NOT undergo surgery until your immune system is back to peak performance. Do not risk getting a mrsa or c-diff infection (they are becoming extremely common). Check out www.hospitalinfection.org for more information on how you can protect yourself. Good luck with everything!

Posts.Content: Jun 9, 2009 05:36PM - edited Jun 9, 2009 05:36PM by swimangel72 Have you received your pathology report and talked to a medical oncologist? Usually your treatment plan is determined by the oncologist, not the surgeon. Also you can't assume just because you get a mastectomy that you won't need chemo - you probably won't need radiation, unless the tumor was close to your chest wall. Lumpectomy with radiation is equal in survival AND recurrence rates to mastectomy. I thought that my mastectomy would be enough (considering my tumor was "just" Stage 1 and Grade 2 - but later, to my dismay, learned taht I still needed chemo when the FISH report showed that the tumor was Her2+++. My advice is - do NOT make any hasty decisions - make an appointment with a medical oncologist before deciding what kind of treatment, including surgery, that you need. Be sure you understand your pathology report - and if necessary - get a second opinion from another oncologist. Good luck and let us know what you decide to do!

After all my complications with the mrsa - my oncologist said it's unfortunate that the surgeons don't send them the patients FIRST - he would have recommended just a lumpectomy with rads for me and I could have avoided so many problems. If you need to cancel your surgery in order to make time to see a medical oncologist - do it! You should at least have a copy of your pathology report in your hand before surgery.........oh, and ask your surgeon to get a second opinion on the pathology report too. My breast cancer surgeon said he never performs surgery without a second OUTSIDE opinion on the reading - because pathology labs have made errors in the past.

Posts.Title: lumpectomy vs. mastectomy? kira Shirlann

Posts.Content: May 12, 2008 06:06PM swimangel72 wrote: Kira - this is one of the toughest decisions you can make. I'm so sorry you have to go through this! I too felt rushed - because I really wanted to get the cancer out. So much depends on the size of your breast tissue now.........I was a "barely B" and not to much in "love" with my breast, so I knew that a mastectomy would bring me much peace-of-mind, especially when my surgeon told me recurrence rates are MUCH lower with mastectomy than with lumpectomy/radiation. If you go for a lumpectomy you will need radiation - something that did not appeal to me, for many reasons. I felt that a mastectomy would "get it all" and I was willing to live with a prothesis. However, I was happily surprised to find out about the Diep reconstruction option which leaves very little scarring if done immediately after the mastectomy. So I had a unilateral skin-sparing mastectomy followed by an immediate Diep. I was home in 5 days and doing well - until I ended up back in the hospital because of a staph infection. The healing of my abdomen has been painfully slow, but I'm almost there now. If I didn't get that infection, I could have returned to work after 8 weeks.  I'm happy now that I went through it all......after my Stage 2 surgery my new "foob" will be hard to tell from the other "real" one. The decision for a lumpectomy or a mastectomy is very personal and difficult - what you need to do is look closely at your pathology report, look at what kind of recurrence rate your cancer has, and see what you're comfortable doing. Since you have a wedding in just 4 weeks, perhaps you're better off doing the lumpectomy first and see if they can get clean margins. You can always opt for a mastectomy later - especially if they don't get clean margins, or if your lymph nodes show cancer, or your Her2 status is positive, or your Oncotype DX score is high......these tests all take time, but it helps you to decide on your treatment plan. Good luck Kira - and stay in touch! We'd like to hear what you decide - AND to hear all about the wedding (did you get your gown yet?)

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2009 02:51PM swimangel72 wrote: Herceptin is the way to go - I wouldn't refuse it if I were you. My tumor was only .9cm with no node involvement - but once they told me the tumor was Her2++++ there was no choice but to get Herceptin. Her2+ tumors are VERY aggressive! Do your research and see what the recurrence rates are - and read some of the stories at www.her2support.org from the women with mets who weren't able to get Herceptin. Fortunately I was able to get a "mild" chemo (Navelbine every two weeks for 4 months with the Herceptin) so I didn't suffer hair loss or any additional heart risks. The Herceptin plus chemo reduces your risk of recurrence 50%.........my Oncotype DS score was 23 - which put me at a 14% risk for recurrence. The Herceptin and chemo reduced my risk to 7%. I don't like to gamble with my life - other people are more comfortable with gambling. If you are still in doubt, get a second opinion from another oncologist Good luck with everything and may God's angels watch over you!

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2009 08:54PM swimangel72 wrote: Hi Movin on - I'm so sorry that you've been dx'd so young! Your dx is similar to mine - except I am Her2+++.......do you know what your Her2 status is? I had decided to get a mastectomy and Diep recon even before knowing my Her2 status. Still it was a shock to learn that I'd need chemo and Herceptin - I thought by going the radical route of mastectomy I could avoid chemo. I agree with the other women who have advised you to seek out the genetic testing. If you end up BRCA1 or 2 positive, then it may give you more confidence moving ahead with a bi-lat and recon. However, if you're negative - and you're Her2-, you may wish to take a less radical approach and go for the lumpectomy and rads. The mastectomy and recon surgery is difficult.............you can end up with many complications you never envisioned. Besides the MRSA staph infection which destroyed my abdominal muscles (and now I need more surgery to repair the big bulge) - I am saddened that I have lost sensation in the skin from my abdominal incision, up past my navel and to my chest bone. I also have no feeling in my new foob so I'm glad that I kept the other breast. I know how scary the shock of a dx first is - how quickly we can c ome to a decision - but it's ok to change your mind. Yes it is a very personal decision - but don't rush; take your time - get a second and even a third opinion before you move forward. And good luck with everything - I'm sorry you've joined us on this roller-coaster ride.

My cancer was even smaller than  yours - everyone kept saying it "wasn't that serious".........even after MRI's of both breasts showed no other cancers, my doctor was so thorough he ordered MRI's of both my hips since I complained about hip pain (turned out to be arthritis) - and he even gave me a complete bone scan. Because I am who I am (jumping into the ocean all at once, riding the front seat of the roller-coaster type of person) I opted for a skin-sparing mastectomy followed immediately by Diep (because I saw my dad die of brain cancer at the age of 59). I'm glad I did the mastectomy (not saying YOU should be so aggressive) - because my Her2 status took a LONG time to come back - and when it did (just last week) it turns out I'm positive. So I'm happy my breast doctor was as aggressive as I was all along. My oncologist is just as aggressive - and I'll be starting on chemo and Herceptin soon. Bottom line - get a second opinion - and I hope they agree that you need MRI's done on both breasts. Good luck - and I'm sorry you have to go through this - but remember, we're all here to help each other!

Posts.Content: Jun 11, 2008 08:37PM swimangel72 wrote: Kim I'm so happy your nodes were negative - that's a big plus! As for my tx - I knew nothing about chemo at all, and was shocked when my onc said I needed it - but this was immediately after he found out I was Her2+. So - no - I didn't "negotiate" with him at all.....he's an amazing man, very intelligent - has done many studies of his own - and came highly recommended. He discussed with me all the recent studies done with Herceptin and their outcomes and said he didn't like some of the chemo drugs used in conjunction with Herceptin because they aggravated the heart problems and that since I was Stage 1, Grade 1, I didn't need such strong meds.  He decided to use Navelbine because a recent study showed that Herceptin worked well in node-negative Stage 1, Grade 1 patients like me, as long as it was given with ANY chemo drug - not alone. I didn't get an "official" second opinion -  however, a friend of my husband's is a doctor who's SISTER is the head of oncology at a major hospital in California. I emailed her my entire sob story and she wrote back and said my onc is right on target with everything and I should feel very comfortable moving forward with this treatment. Sometimes I do feel nervous though since I don't know any other women on Herceptin and Navelbine who are early stagers like me.....most women on this regime have mets...........but, I realize everyone's cancer (and family history) is very different and ultimately it comes down to trusting your onc. Kim if you're not satisfied with the treatment suggestions from your onc, be sure you go for a second (and even third) opinion. It'll put your mind at rest.  Oh and how goofy am I? I can't stop hearing the Mary Poppins song "Just a spoonful of sugar helps the medicine go down"........wouldn't we all love a magical Mary Poppins-nurse when we get our chemo tx - with rosy cheeks and no warts too!  No matter what happens Kim - remember - chemo isn't forever - you can get through it - all the women here are like Mary Poppins for me!

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2008 03:15PM swimangel72 wrote: My breast surgeon requested a second opinion on my path report as a matter of routine - he said he NEVER performs surgery until he gets a second opinion. Later, my original oncologist requested a second Fish test because he said it was very unusual to be Her2+ and Stage 1 and Grade 2. Unfortunately, both second opinions confirmed the first. Then I took it upon my self to get a second opinion from a second oncologist because I wasn't absolutely sure about his ideas for my tx........oncology is an art as well as a science too......the second onc agreed with my first onc (as did another oncologist - my husband's friend's sister, who is a head onc at a major hospital).....AND I wrote to a web site called  "Ask an oncologist now" and received an email back also agreeing with my unusual tx - here's the web site:  http://www.askanoncologistnow.com/cancer/question/ So yes - a second opinion is definitely worth the price for peace-of-mind. Don't hesitate to go for it!

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2009 09:04PM - edited Nov 6, 2009 09:09PM by swimangel72 I had an enlarged lymph gland in my groin -  many years ago (in my wild-20's) before BC. I felt fine too - no fevers, chills, etc. My ob/gyn at that time did a pap smear and said I had something going on there - he did cyro-surgery and put me on antibiotics and that took care of the problem. Perhaps it was some kind of STD..........not that I'd wish an STD on anyone - but compared to BC, they look like VERY treatable problems don't you think? Good luck and I'll be sending a prayer that your results are B9. P.S. Years later (after my 3rd c-section) I had what I thought was another swollen lymph gland in my groin on the opposite side - went to my ob/gyn and he shocked me by saying this one WAS a hernia! I had out-patient surgery where they put in a teany-tiny piece of mesh and that was the end of that. So it's not uncommon to confuse a hernia with a swollen lymph gland.

Posts.Content: May 23, 2008 07:32PM swimangel72 wrote: Hi Sarmcl - I had a unilateral mastectomy on March 3, 2008 followed by an immediate Diep - my surgery took about 6 hours. I stayed in the hospital from Monday through Friday - and went home with three drainage tubes and pain pills. I had to be readmitted the following Sunday due to shortness of breath - and they kept me there another 11 days due to a shaph infection in my abdomen. I was then sent home with an open abdominal incision (which is finally beginning to close) and more antibiotics. I'm still not permitted to return to work - my surgeon put me back on MORE antibiotics (because now my port scar is infected.) So much depends on how your surgery proceeds - what kind of reconstruction surgery are you anticipating? Are you planning on implants or a free-Tram or Diep? I chose the Diep because it would come the closest to matching my healthy breast and I didn't want any problems with my muscles. Also I didn't want an implant under my chest-wall muscles since I'm a swimmer. Complications like mine can occur even with very minimal surgery, so please don't let me get you too worried! You are MUCH younger than me.......and if you have a strong immune system you should be fine no matter what surgery you choose, as long as your surgeons are very experienced. Good luck and God bless you with a positive outcome!

Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2008 02:04PM swimangel72 wrote: Hi - I had an nearly identical pathology report - Stage 1, Grade 1 is excellent news! Er+ and PR+ is also good news - the treatments are very effective. However, the jury is still out on your Her2 status.........mine was also 2+ which means "equivacal" - and it was also sent out for FISH analysis. My oncologist was shocked when my Fish report came back positive - so shocked that he sent it out to a second lab for another opinion. It returned positive as well, so to my great dismay I had to start on chemo. The good news is that Herceptin really works so well against Her2+ tumors and the side effects are very light. So even though it's unusual to be Her2+ with Stage 1 and Grade 1, it's not impossible. Be sure you get a follow-up report on your Fish results!

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2008 10:24AM swimangel72 wrote: My surgeon told me that if I had a lump with rads, my chance for a recurrence would be 14%, but if I did the unilateral mastectomy, my odds of recurrence (using him as my surgeon) would be 0% (because he's such a great surgeon. While I didn't buy into HIS egotistical logic, I knew I didn't want rads and knew that for my own peace-of-mind a mastectomy made sense. I opted for a skin-sparing mastectomy with immediate reconstruction with a Diep flap - unfortunately this turned into a muscle-sparing free tram, which would have been fine, except I then developed a MRSA staph infection in my abdomen which meant another 2 weeks in the hospital on IV drugs - then home with an opened, debrided abdominal incision that needed packing for 3 months. Later on, I realized that my surgeon didn't give me the correct facts - that recurrence of cancer is equal with lump/rads or mastectomy. This is an important scientific fact - RECURRENCE RATES ARE THE SAME (new studies prove this.) So now I wish that I just went with the lump/rads. I also erroneously thought that a mastectomy would mean I wouldn't need chemo - WRONG! I never saw an oncologist until after my surgery - another big mistake on my part. The surgeon and plastic surgeon had rushed me into surgery so fast my head was spinning! And it fed my fear to "get it out". I should have slowed down and spent more time researching. Turns out that my tumor was Her2+ and my Oncotype DX score was 22 - in the low end of the intermediate stage. Thus my onc said I needed Herceptin and chemo anyway - and more surgery to implant a port -which also got infected and had to be removed - needless to say, I'm NEVER returning to that hospital! The good news is that at least I didn't need radiation - and my new foob "took" even if I still have major surgery down the road to repair my huge abdominal hernia. I've since switched plastic surgeons to one who is truly an artist and will make this fat foob look like a real breast. Through all this I've never regretted keeping my "good girl". For years it has never shown even the slightest sign of problems, not even calcifications. My "bad girl" always had calcifications - even at my very first mammo when I was just 37. Now my question is "Why didn't my old radiologists and ob/gyn ever TELL me that my breast had calcifications and that I should keep a close eye on it?" They never said ANYTHING to me - just "everything's normal, come back next year." So I skipped 3 years worth of mammo's while we were moving and I was getting my daughters off to college. If I knew that calcifications were something to keep a watchful eye on, I would have been more vigilant. ANYWAY - I'm happy I still have my "good" breast. No matter that it's small and a bit saggy - it FEELS alive and my new foob doesn't. That's one thing that's often not discussed - how after a mastectomy the nerves are cut and your breast (including the skin) feels "dead". Oh - and how the area around my navel also feels dead after the free-tram. If I ever get breast cancer in my good girl, I'm not going to reconstruct that side. I've had enough surgery and infections to last the rest of my life!

Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2008 05:06AM swimangel72 wrote: I'm sorry I haven't been keeping up with everyone on this thread, I forgot to check! My own chemo has had ups and downs........after switching oncs, I didn't realize they ADDED drugs to my Navelbine and Herceptin regime - specifically, Zofran and Decadron. The former (an anti-nausea med) caused me terrible constipation and 3 days later awful stomach cramping - and the latter (a steroid) prevented me from sleeping for 2 nights in a row. Also - they had to remove my mediport because the infection never did heal, so my infusions have been going into my veins. My arm was so painful the first week..........I ended up back on pain meds. But let me say I LOVE my new nurses........last Wednesday, at my request, they took me off the Zofran and Decadron (because the chemo never made me nauseous before) - and then instead of flushing my vein with a bag of saline before the Navelbine, they ran both through my veins at the same time. WHAT A DIFFERENCE! My arm felt fine - I had no constipation or stomach cramping - no more sleepness nights!  I was back to the manageable SEs I had gotten accustomed to at my first onc's office (painless diarhea for about 5 hours after treatment - some tiredness, some hair thinning and fingernails splitting.) I have only two more infusions of Navelbine - then it's just Herceptin every two weeks till next April - and Arimidex for five years. I'm not looking forward to getting any joint pains because I already have arthritis in my hips. I had minor hot flashes when I went through menopause so maybe it won't be too bad for me on the AI. I'm going to try to stay positive and try to keep swimming as much as I can - and try to lose weight. My goal is 25 pounds before next summer when my PS says he can do my revision surgery. I scheduled an appointment with a spine doctor - because the MRI on my lower back showed spinal stenosis and a herniated disc which may be causing the hip pain (it's so bad somedays I feel like a crippled old woman). This way I can start on physical therapy if necessary BEFORE starting on Arimidex. Also, my thyroid levels have dropped - I'm scheduled for a sonogram of my thryoid tomorrow - hopefully I won't need to go on even more meds. I'm looking forward to returning to work when school starts in September - but I'm nervous because I don't want to be the new "poster child" for BC......my co-workers are all wonderful, but I get embarassed by the extra attention. They haven't seen me since my surgery in March and inevitably they'll be looking me up and down to see if I changed. But the show must go on.........and so must I. Otter I hope your hair will start growing back soon - I'll be interested in reading about your experience with Arimidex and yours too Nancy. Some of the stories I've read are awful......but since my tumor was ER+ at 90%, I hope the SEs aren't too bad.

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2009 11:18AM - edited Dec 2, 2009 11:21AM by swimangel72 Welcome Gina and Kelley - and all new Stage 1 Sisters - I'm so sorry I haven't been on this thread in a while. Gina I just had my final reconstruction on Monday and I was also extremely nervous. I suppose the thought of anesthesia and infections never leave our minds..........but I'm happy to report that I woke up in the recovery room without any nauseousness, and very little pain. A bit of a twinge where they put in the drain, but otherwise, nada! Extra-strength Tylenol was all I needed after the first night..........and I think to myself, but of course, all my nerve endings were removed during the mastectomy! You could put ice on my foob and I wouldn't feel it similar to Mrs. Doubtfire, lol. I'm not allowed to get my bandages wet - my sweet plastic surgeon will perform my "unveiling" this coming Friday - so I'm looking forward to seeing the fipple and areola. It's been a long long journey, but I've been blessed with a wonderful supportive DH who makes me laugh every day - fantastic kids - and a job I love (with women there who have been through worse cancers than myself). I never joined a support group other than bc.org - like you Gina, I felt a bit guilty that my BC was "only" a Stage 1. Still I hope to convey messages of optimism and caution with my writings here - especially with surgeries that put all of us at risk for mrsa. Once again, everyone please check out www.hospitalinfection.org to better prepare yourself to avoid mrsa or c-diff. I will never ever again take hospitalization or surgeries lightly........no matter for what reason! I was a wreck when one of our teachers' needed surgery to repair his hip.......at the same hospital where I got mrsa............thank God he came through with flying colors! Now - I must admit - my worst pain these days is no longer my hip (that cortisone shot REALLY did the trick!) It's my upper neck.........and I know why it bothers me so much..........because I spend way too much time writing on my computer, lol! Have a wonderful day my sweet sisters!

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2009 01:37AM - edited Jul 26, 2009 01:45AM by swimangel72 Millie - you NEED to know what kind of infection you had. No one told me I had MSRA until I started complaining to the insurance company nurse (who called me every two weeks with an angel's voice!) She was worried about me and checked her files on me and lo-and-behold SHE was the first person to tell me I had contracted MRSA!  No thanks to ANY of the doctors or nurses! Of course they try to keep a low-profile about MRSA in the hospital (afraid of law-suits and bad press). I immediately went to the Records department at the hospital and got copies of all my hospital reports - there it was, spelled out in black and white - and all the notes from the specialists, including an infectious disease specialist. It wasn't until a year later this past May, when I was going for Stage 2 free-tram revisions, that my NEW plastic surgeon advised me to get checked again for MRSA with their infectious disease specialist. He had to swab my nose, underarms and groin - I was SHOCKED to learn that MRSA was cultivated (meaning alive but dormant) in my nostrils! I had to apply an antibiotic ointment twice-a-day in that area for 10 days, then get rechecked (it was then negative, thank God) before my PS would perform surgery. I was VERY angry that neither my breast surgeon nor old PS recommended that I get rechecked for MRSA............I was walking around with it in my nostrils for a YEAR! Don't these doctors have ANY conscience at all? Oh - and btw - vancomyacin isn't the only antibiotic they use - when they tried to give it to my prophylactically before my abdominal hernia repair surgery on July 10th, I immediately got a rash on my arm and the nurse stopped the IV and they switched me to ZYVOX which is very effective, but very expensive. Anyway Millie - try to get copies of all your operative/hospital reports. It's good to keep a file at home, especially if you ever need to go for a second opinion - or just to act as an advocate for yourself (which is so important in today's world of rush-rush medicine). Good luck and I hope you continue healing well! ited to add:  To understand WHY I get so angry about hospital-acquired infections please check out http://www.hospitalinfection.org/. Their 15 steps to protect yourself from infection is very helpful.

Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2009 10:53PM swimangel72 wrote: Hi Nicole - thanks for the update, I was thinking about your mom. What was her Oncotype DX results? Did she already start chemo and does it include Herceptin? I had a skin-sparing mastectomy with immediate recon lke your mom is thinking about - the "added bonus of a tummy tuck" really enticed me, but unfortunately, I ended up with a staph infection in my abdomen and now look like I'm 8 months pregnant due to the hernia that developed. I'm not trying to get you more worried Nicole - I just hope you can help your mom do the research to choose a VERY experienced plastic surgeon who has done HUNDREDS or THOUSANDS of these surgeries. There are many choices to make, even with the tummy fat - will your mom get a Diep flap (where they only remove the fat and no abdominal muscle) or a "free-tram" where they remove a small piece of muscle to help the veins survive - or a pedicle tram - where they remove the fat but leave it attached to the stomach muscle and tunnel it upwards through the abdominal cavity to create a new breast? I hope she can get the Diep - it really causes the least amount of problems with the stomach muscles afterwards. Here's a helpful web page my new plastic surgeon on Long Island developed: www.breastreconstruction.org Oh and there's another very experienced Diep surgeon in Manhattan at Beth Israel Hospital - his name is Mark Smith. Several women here have used him and have been happy. You could also go to the Breast Reconstruction forum and search for information there. Good luck - I'll be praying for your mom!

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2010 03:23PM swimangel72 wrote: I agree with MarieKelly's observations - that "If I had to choose between believing the Oncotype score or believing the assigned grade, I would believe the Oncotype score." My situation is the reverse of yours - my tumor had a LOW grade (Grade 1) yet my Oncotype score was intermediate (22) - at first my oncologist said I didn't need chemo - yet he was confused because of this discrepancy. Thankfully he questioned his first advice to me, went through the paperwork on my case and saw that my FISH report was never received (due to errors on the part of my breast surgeon's office). When my onc finally received the results of my FISH report, he was shocked to discover that my tumor was Her2++++...........thus his treatment plan for me changed drastically - and I needed chemo for 4 months with Herceptin for a year. Therefore, it is important for you to get a second opinion - the discrepancy must be accounted for - at least to give you peace-of-mind. Good luck and I hope it turns out you really don't need chemo!

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2008 06:40PM swimangel72 wrote: I had a free-flap and was sent home with 4 drains but no antibiotics. Perhaps that's the normal protocol for implant reconstruction, I don't know, but  I wish my PS did put me on antibiotics - I ended up with a MRSA staph infection in my abdomen! I had been very clean at home - but it was too late; I got the infection either during my 7 hour surgery or afterwards during my 5 day stay at the hospital. So you are being very vigilant about cleaning your laundry - but be MORE vigilant during your hospital stay. Tell anyone who comes in your room to visit you that they need to wash their hands; most hospital rooms have antibacterial hand wash at the door to the rooms - don't be shy - you should even remind your doctors and nurses to wash their hands. Other women have taken antibacterial wipes and/or wipes with Bleach to wipe down things in their hospital room, including the railings, doorknobs, etc. Here's a copy of a recent article in AARP regarding MRSA and C. difficile: ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ THE VILLAIN: MRSA Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) can live harmlessly on the skin. But when it gets into the body, it can wreak havoc, causing fever, chills, and a full-body rash, among other symptoms. In healthy people, a properly treated infection is usually confined to the skin around a cut or a scrape. Those who have weakened immune systems or are recovering from illness should take extra precautions, however. Best Defense * Wash up Keep hands scrupulously clean (see sidebar for tips). If you're in the hospital, ask visitors and docs to wash their hands when they enter the room. * Bring your own snips Shared facilities are high-risk MRSA environments. Tote your own tools to manicure appointments, and wear flip-flops in the gym shower. And pack two towels-one for machines and a second to dry off with. * Don't pick Wash cuts and scrapes well; cover them until they're fully healed. Call the doc if... your skin develops pus-filled pimples or boils. MRSA is resistant to penicillin and certain other antibiotics but can be treated with other drugs.  Hand Washing 101 What they didn't terach you in kindergarten 1. Use warm water Excessively hot water is hard on your skin, and cold water inhibits the sudsing of soap. 2. Don't sweat the soap You don't need to kill germs with pricey antibacterial soap. Just dislodge them with a good lather. 3. Hit the hot spots Soap up every millimeter of skin, including the thumbs, the backs of the hands, and the undersides of nails. 4. Rinse repeatedly Use running water, and lots of it, to remove every last trace of suds (and germs). 5. Save your work Faucet taps can be loaded with germs. Use a paper towel to shut off the water. THE VILLAIN: C. difficile The Clostridium difficile bacterium strikes at the gut, triggering severe diarrhea. It lives harmlessly in many people's intestines, held in check by other bacteria, says Patricia Raymond, M.D., an assistant professor of clinical medicine at Eastern Virginia Medical School. "When strong antibiotics wipe out what we call these ‘friendly flora,' C. difficile can proliferate." Best Defense * Keep clean Frequent hand washing helps. And if you're bed-bound in the hospital, keep a hand-sanitizing gel nearby for your own and others' use. * Don't be pill hungry Antibiotics can be lifesavers for those who need them. But if your doctor says they probably won't help you, don't insist on a prescription. * Add friendly flora If you do need an antibiotic, ask your doc about a probiotic, helpful yeast called Saccharomyces boulardii (commonly sold under the brand name Florastor). Call the doc if...you develop diarrhea that lasts longer than 24 hours or is accompanied by weakness, a racing heart rate, or blood in the stool. --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Here's a link to another AARP article written by a doctor on how to avoid infections in healthcare settings: http://bulletin.aarp.org/yourhealth/healthyliving/articles/finding_your_way_2.html
